review: The Band was of outsized influence given its relatively small recording output and only one certifiably classic album "The Band"). And it's hard to caThe Band was of outsized influence given its relatively small recording output and only one certifiably classic album "The Band"). And it's hard to call them influential as they bucked the psychedelic/heavy metal trends of the day with their rootsy, literate storytelling music that featured accordions, mandolins, and haiku-tight guitar solos. At the time they were almost a curious (if incredibly talented with a dozen indelibly great songs) anachronism only cited as influential much later by bands like Counting Crows. They also helped made rock culturally respectable when they landed on the cover of Time magazine in 1969. But in other respects The Band was everywhere and most especially in the thick of Bob Dylan's electric revolution that created folk rock. The Band backed up Dylan's first full-blown electric tour and had to endure the jeers, boos, catcalls and outright threats made by folk purists during a worldwide tour. (In addition, Dylan was essentially a solo artist and had to learn how to lead and play with a band.)Somewhat curiously, Robertson focuses the book on the first 33 years of his life leading up to and including their final Last Waltz concert, memorialized in Martin Scorcese's flawed but wonderful film of 1978. I'm still debating whether this was a good choice, but probably yes. We are spared Robertson trying to breath life and significance into his later works (a couple of pretty good solo albums and film scores) and moreover the tragic declines of his bandmates Richard Manuel (suicide), Rick Danko (died in sleep at age 56), and Levon Helm (cancer)--verily the voices of The Band as Robertson limited himself to writing, brilliant guitar fills, and background vocals. Also he only hints at the decline of his marriage. Thus he avoids one weakness of Keith Richards' "Life": Keith's attempts to make us care about the recording of "Bridges of Babylon," duets with Ronnie Wood, and details of his later domestic happiness in a Connecticut mansion. On the other hand, Robertson's 1976 curfew makes for an oddly impersonal narrative; it's a more novelistic, neatly tied up ending that omits the wages of years of substance abuse, and the ultimate outcomes of the "band of brothers" The Band became. Robertson's wacky family history (half-native American, half Jewish mobsters in Toronto) makes for a good intro. The formative years touring with Ronnie Hawkins and the Hawks are a bit protracted but they do explain how four Canadians slowly annexed a Southern rock and roll roadhouse band while the Deep South seeped into their bones (and Robertson's lyrics), leading to classics like "The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down" and "Unfaithful Servant." Musicians will especially enjoy Robertson's detailed account of the recording process, which The Band upended by rejecting sound baffles, isolation chambers, and overdubs. Essentially they chose to record live; at least for their first two albums, which sound as though they were made in a pine-panelied living room. (Despite the woodsy, Upstate New York vibe of The Band's eponymous album, it was recorded in LA, in a retrofitted house once owned by Sammy Davis Jr.)Somewhat disappointing are the (perhaps inevitable) show-biz trappings of the narrative. Names are dropped like notes in a self-indulgent solo, from Jimmy Carter all the way down to Larry Hagman. Band-members who dressed like sharecroppers bought Mercedes 600 limos with rear curtains. Refreshingly though, Bob Dylan emerges as a real character, pretty much a normal guy who drives a blue station wagon and dotes on his wife and kids (granted this was the "New Morning" phase). As other ers have observed, Robertson's storytelling skills are excellent (if too frequently self-serving) and the writing highly uneven. ...more

review: Days of Rage reads like a thriller full of shoot-em-up scenes, jailbreaks, and hair-raising escapes. Unfortunately it's all true and people really dieDays of Rage reads like a thriller full of shoot-em-up scenes, jailbreaks, and hair-raising escapes. Unfortunately it's all true and people really died in a 10-year scourge of bombings and shootings by the radical underground--Weatherman, Panthers, Symbionese, Puerto Rican Liberation Front and more. Although Burroughs clearly sympathizes with the innocent cops, Brinks drivers, cabbies, and others who were slaughtered, the book does not dodge the moral question of when acts of terror may in fact be justified as acts of war. This issue dogs us today as we face many outbursts of terrorism globally. What are oppressed people to do when they are unrepresented with no political options for change, or a moral imperative to take any means necessary to stop wrong-doing at the top or rife throughout society? I abhor attacks on abortion clinics, Tel Aviv buses, Parisian cafes, etc., but you can understand the twisted logic that leads to such drastic and tragic action. That said, Burroughs portrays many of the terrorists as rich kids playing dangerous games (Bill Ayers and Bernadine Dorhn come to mind), corrupt, or perhaps deluded or deranged (the Patty Hearst-kidnapping SLA). Fascinatingly, much of this history has been forgotten, even by folks like me, who came of age in this era, and lived in the prime targets of DC and NYC. Also interesting, much of the action occurred well after American radicalism peaked (probably 1968-70) and certainly after it plunged as the Vietnam War wound down and ended. To the end, the Radical fringe was sure it would ignite a violent, grassroots uprising. As interviewed by Burroughs, many Radical survivors today recognize the errors of their thinking. It might be comforting to know that their numbers were tiny. Often fewer than 10 people supporting an entire organization with only two or three trigger-pullers and bomb-planters at the core. Gaining even one recruit was cause for celebration. It makes you wonder how many violent radical Islamic operatives exist. Less comforting, it only takes a couple of folks with bombs and machine guns to make the appearance of a large fand well-organized network--part of the "beauty" of terrorism.The FBI and other law-enforcement agencies agreed the saw a threat writ large. They spent years and countless resources trying to track down ringleaders with surprisingly little success. Famously they resorted to dirty tricks like illegal wiretaps and burglaries, which backfired when agents (including Richard "Deep Throat" Felt) were indicted and convicted, receiving somewhat harsher sentences than the few radicals who were tracked down or surrendered (although others received life sentences or were shot dead in the streets).The book's most original take is its exploration of what it truly meant to go underground, a topic not previously researched or reported, according to Burroughs. For the Weatherman, it often meant cushy living in rented beach houses, supported by Radical Chic lawyers. For true tough guys like ex-con Ray Lavasseur, it meant faked IDs using the socials of dead infants and constantly moving between ratty "safe houses" while also raising semi-normal families replete with Montessori school educations. Others split for Algeria or Cuba. After I wrote this , I checked others and was surprised to see some so negative. I agree that Burroughs is no left-wing apologist for violent radicals, but neither is this book a Fox-like hatchet job. Clearly he admires the intelligence and perhaps even the moral position of at least some of his subjects. Others were deluded buffoons or trigger-happy charlatans, and he says so. A key pivot of the book is the internal debate between symbolic acts of terror (blowing up empty bathrooms in government buildings at 2 am, for example), vs. overt "kill the pigs" mindset of hunting down cops, or "you can't avoid the collateral of war" (eg, killing innocent bystanders). Interesting that some who inadvertently killed innocent bystanders continued to engage in acts of terror. ...more

Most famous for his work with the Stones, Johns worked with them all including the Beatles, Clapton, Led Zepp, Emmy Lou Harris and lots of minor figures such as Spooky Tooth and the Ozark Mountain Daredevils. This makes Johns a bit of a Zelig as well as perhaps the only coherent person in the room (he claims to have never taken drugs) most of the time. Refreshingly, Johns does not take credit for the success of his employers, truly viewing himself in a conduit to let the talent shine through with empathetic sound. We've all read/seen too many "I-was- the-REAL-genius" books/docs about producers, film editors, backup singers or even a particular sound board. Johns keeps his story and considerable contribution to the side, where it belongs. Although I enjoyed reading this, the book has several glaring weaknesses. One is the lack of insight into the process of making music. This is especially surprising as Johns himself is a fairly accomplished musician who recorded several albums and supposedly had a minor hit in Spain with a cover of "Lady Jane." There are refreshing exceptions such as his decision to record Pete Townsend playing live amid a cluster of 60 string players for the Townsend-Ronnie Wood Album "Rough Cut." Another is his lamentation for the passing of semi-live recording sessions for the studio overdub process that recording musicians one at a time in isolation sound booths. His sympathetic portrayal of Brian Jones is a treat. Another weakness is Johns's show-biz, nice-nice glibness: "He was a lovely chap and unfailingly polite and I regret I did not see him before he died," etc., repeated over and again about many different major and minor characters. (Occasionally he mentions not getting on with someone but at about the same level of detail). Johns himself remains a cipher. You just don't learn much about him beyond a good yarn about accidentally breaking into the industry and references to one or two marriages. The book is neither critical analysis, soul-baring or kiss and tell, so what is it? This pales in comparison to Keith Richards's literate and insightful "Life," for example. They have a longstanding policy of considering colonists French which has led to free immigration from Algeria and Africa in particular). Yet they have hardly mainstreamed all their ethnic strains. The Muslim slums of Paris are but one notorious example.--During the Nazi invasion of WWII, the French were hardly the cheese-mongering surrender monkeys of lore. In fact they fought hard (if briefly) and suffered 130,000 casualties. The fall of Belgium simply left their flank too exposed.--On the other hand the Resistance is a bit of a myth. Bowden's book is apolitical and somewhat amoral on this subject, but it does raise tough questions: what would you do in the face of abject evil? Would you (as a person or a society) have the courage to stand up, even when that evil threatened to blow up you and shoot down one of your kids on their way to school? Is crossing the line into "exra-legal" (eg, illegal) activities justified when that evils engages in international terrorism, political assassinations, and even threatens foreign governments?Of course it is also the story of the world's greatest outlaw, Pablo Escobar, the Colombian coke-smuggling king of the 1980s. A chubby soccer-playing pothead with a calm, soothing and even mesmerizing style of speech, Pablo came from modest, middle-class roots. From a small-time, car-nicking thuggery, he grew a $5 billion empire that included dozens of homes in Colombia and Miami, a huge staff including the vicious sicarios (hit men), and essential ownership (through bribery and intimidation) of hundreds if not thousands of politicians, judges, police and military men. When challenged Pablo would not hesitate to gun down or blow up his rivals, whether they were judges, military commanders, and even a popular anti-narco presidential candidate. He also went after the families of all of the above.Meanwhile Pablo himself threw Gatsby-scaled parties at his Medellin estate stocked with exotic game-park wildlife. Behind Nancy Reagan's "Just So No" slogans where Reagan administration officials seriously worried that cocaine would destabilize our society (you could argue this came true with the crack wars a few years later). The US avoided confronting Pablo until Escobar made a pact with Colombia's communist guerrillas in an effort to control trafficking routes in the jungle. This brought anti-communist special ops into play who worked closely with US ambassador Busby and with Colombian officials.Confronted with this alliance of power, Pablo turned to the people and presented himself as a modern-day Robin Hood or Bonnie and Clyde. His system of cocaine trafficking simply redistributed wealth from foolish, coke-nosed Gringos into a Colombia desperate for investment. Also I had never visited New Orleans and regretted that I missed my chance before it was swept away by a Cat 5 hurricane, broken levees, polluted floodwaters, failed policies. The reason I never visited NOLA was I harbored a deep suspicion that it was a cartoon, a failed city hiding behind a Mardi Gras mask. Sort of like Santa Fe and its adobe Conoco station and tiny, cutesy, contrived core engulfed in a sea of low-rent sprawl. That was my prejudice. Ok, that's a lot of background. I finally went to New Orleans a month ago and was swept away by its depth and complexity. In a city that was 80 percent underwater, decaying for generations, still plagued by corrupt government, lingering segregation, terrible numbers for health, education and crime, and a limp local economy, more than 80 percent have moved back. Poor blacks and white exiled to Baton Rouge or Houston clawed to get back to a semblance of their lives in an unpainted shotgun house. They have been joined by an influx of young musicians and entrepreneurs, some of whom came to rebuild homes as volunteers and just stayed. Rich whites re-invested in stately homes that are really so much termite fodder. We biked all over the city and found new vitality everywhere. It turns out that Bourbon Street is the cartoon, but it is engulfed by richly layered multi-part novel. The book is beautifully researched and written like a fine novel. review: I read this book in preparation for my first trip to New Orleans. Most of what I knew about Long I gleaned from the Randy Newman album "Good Old Boys"I read this book in preparation for my first trip to New Orleans. Most of what I knew about Long I gleaned from the Randy Newman album "Good Old Boys" with songs like "Louisiana 1927" and "Here Come the Kingfish." White's take is a straightforward, relatively concise and highly entertaining look at Long's life, in chronological order, from humble beginnings to corrupt end as a US Senator who posed a serious threat to Franklin Roosevelt's re-election in 1936. One of many conspiracy theories surrounding Long's death (assassinated by Dr. Carl Weiss in the Louisiana State Capitol in 1935) is that FDR was behind it. Long was one of the most talented yet least scrupulous and disciplined politicians of all time. When each one of Louisiana's newspapers opposed Long, he started his own daily mouthpiece and subsidized it by requiring every state employee to subscribe. Kickback and graft schemes were legendary. He accepted only cash which he stored in his Deduct Box (which resembled a giant ballot box). He hid the Deduct Box and died without revealing the location. It has never been found. Supposedly it was stuffed with more than $1 million in cash as well as papers and photos damaging to his enemies. You can see a replica in the opulent Roosevelt Hotel in New Orleans, a place Long was drawn to for its party scene although he detested (and ultimately dismantled) its "Old Regular" power structure.Long had many enemies whom he sought to destroy not just defeat. He instructed to the state legislature to outlaw the sale of funeral insurance, which happened to be the occupation of one vanquished opponent. He attacked opponents with profane epithets and accusations ranging from supporting blacks to beastiality. He called one genteel opponent with a Col. Sanders beard "Old Feather Duster." He threatened rivals with fisticuffs and firearms and employed the State National Guard to do his bidding, including an armed invasion and occupation of New Orleans. Long consolidated power by rigging elections, bribes, threats, and packing the legislature and courts with his lackeys. When elected to the US Senator he briefly retained his position as Governor and later continued to run the state through his proxy O.K. Allen. Through such remote control, he rammed through dozens of bills penned by Long himself with virtually no floor debate or opposition. This gave him total control over all patronage, courts, and even appointed positions in New Orealns. He was shameless. He once took a parish vote unanimously with more voters than registered by at least 500. In the Senate he became a scourge to FDR and refused to disburse New Deal funds within Louisiana. In 1932 Long stumped for FDR (who found Long's pig-in-the-sty eating habits and dandified outfits appalling) but by 1935 he spoke of opposing FDR as a third party candidate. Pundits thought a Long-led ticket could take 3 million votes and throw the election to the Republicans.Long generated fierce and vitriolic opposition. Prominent New Orleans residents spoke openly of assassination. J. Edgar Hoover sought to snag Long on tax evasion and may have been close when Long died. He was almost impeached and censured several times. With his back to the wall, Long employed two strategics. First he would turn to he populist base, the poorest of Louisiana poor. Long had a genuine commitment to elevating the lot of poor whites (otherwise he was initially as racist as they come)by providing free textbooks and building roads, clinics and schools. To pay he took on Standard Oil and the Baton Rouge refineries by dramatically raising their taxes. The poor whites of Louisiana supported the Kingfish unconditionally and would rally to his side as needed within hours.(Long favored radical redistribution of wealth to be funded by corporate taxes and caps on personal income. While his goals were socialists, he used the means of a fascist and was often accused of being a dictator.) Second, Long could switch on a dime from ranting demagogue to the most persuasive and rational orator. He possessed a keen (and largely self-taught) legal mind and could build a case like a Darrow or Bailey. Time and again he painted himself into the tightest quarters and literally talked his way out. He also was a master of the media: vanity newspapers, radio, and a medium he invented: roving trucks mounted with giant loudspeakers. If you've seen "Oh Brother, Where Art Thou," you get the idea.When Long died (he might have been saved if surgeons rushing from New Orleans had not crashed their car; an inexperienced doctor botched the operation to remove a bullet), huge crowds attended his funeral. For years many refused to believe he was dead. He was the Elvis of Southern politics. He left his mark everywhere; from artifacts at the Roosevelt Hotel to the massive Huey P. Long Bridge in New Orleans; to the 450-foot-tall State Capitol spire he had designed and built in one year in Baton Rouge and a complete overhaul of his beloved LSU. review: For starters, here is the Told Story. In 1919, a young military man named Eisenhower joined a convoy a trucks attempting to cross America from DC to CFor starters, here is the Told Story. In 1919, a young military man named Eisenhower joined a convoy a trucks attempting to cross America from DC to California. Within 38 miles of leaving the convoy broke down. It took months to plod across roadless America and the entire mission was almost entirely lost in the Great Salt Desert. Intended to demonstrate military might and mobility, the mission turned into a fiasco. Eisenhower promised to do something about it someday--and he did as President in the 1950s, signing into law an act creating the Interstate Highway System.This did happen but there is a back story that is somewhat less and also more interesting. In the 1890s bicycling became popular. A dearth of paved roads made longer rides impossible. A young bicycle promoter named Carl Fisher helped start a Good Roads movement. Early in the next century cars came along and immediately caught on. But there were still no good roads. Rails connected towns and cities. Within cities, horses (and horse urine and poop) and streetcars were the rule. Fisher dropped bicycles and immediately began applying his considerable promotional skills to the auto. He helped launch the Indianapolis Speedway (with disastrous and fatal initial results) and opened an auto showroom downtown. He was addicted to gimmicks like dropping an auto (secretly reinforced) off the roof of his showroom. The Goods Roads movement was taken up statewide but somewhat ad hoc, Chamber of Commerce-like groups. About 1920 this enterprise was turned over to colorless bureaucrats and starchy engineers who truly launched the system--routes, funding, engineering standards, construction techniques. The author is unfortunately smitten with this group and overloads the biographical detail. (An exception is the Lear-ian RObert Moses, who has a small role in this book and is much better explicated by Robert Caro in The Power Broker.) Come the 1950s and the book jumps to life as the unintended consequences of the Interstates become apparent. In 1958, Lewis Mumford launches an attack on the Interstates that galvanizes a movement. In the 1960s, protests against Interstates being rammed through cities as a form of "urban removal" sound one of the major notes of a turbulent decade. In the narrative, the faceless bureaucrats fall into retreat to be bested by heroes of historic preservation, racial equity, and neighborhood rights. What makes the book work so well is Swift's balance. He sees the good and the bad of the Interstates and is able to amplify both equally. A major point that I agree with (although I am a proponent of walking, cycling, compact cities, and mass transit), is that the rise of the auto and highways was a popular movement. Americans fell in love with the auto from the get-go and clamored for highway construction well into the 1960s and 70s. In 1972, Jack and his wife Diane came to the Pacific lowlands near Dominical to manage a cattle ranch and rice fields. The Colorado natives found the ranching poor but they were enamored by the flora and fauna in five discrete ecosystems located on their Hacienda Baru. In the 1990s the Ewings bought a stake in the ranch and began to shut down agricultural operations. They planned to let the rice paddies and pastures regrow into native mangrove and cloud forest; to build a small eco-resort; and to train local people as guides through this rich environment full of toucans, monkeys and more.I had a huge respect for this undertaking but was doubtful. In 1991, Hacienda Baru was a long way from anywhere over poor roads. The idea of ecotourism was new and unproven. Would people pay to tramp through the forest and stay in rustic cabins? At the time Costa Rica operated under more of a Hawaiian resort model emphasizing beaches and large, air-conditioned motels.This year my family returned to Costa Rica for 10 days of volunteer work and tourism. I wondered if Jack and Diane had succeeded or even if they were still alive. Google quickly led me to the web site of what appeared to be a thriving enterprise. I was pleasantly surprised to learn that Hacienda Baru has been designated a National Wildlife Refuge. Then Amazon Kindle led me to this book, which I bought right away and read in Costa Rica. During the trip we stayed at Hacienda Baru and reconnected with the Ewings, now in their late 60s, and employing more than 30 locals who work running an open-air restaurant, gardens, and lodging in simple screened cabins, along with a thriving rainforest guide service that attracts busloads each day. We had a small, private tour with a guide named Olman who grew up in a peasant household learning to track animals. He still tracks them expertly, but only to see, not hunt. We learned that Jack wrote the book as a series of guest columns for local publications in Costa Rica. The essays are short meditations on the natural phenomena of Hacienda Baru based on Jack's own careful observations. You learn how a leaf-ant colony has an amazing social order for 5 million individuals; that the charismatic toucan is a ruthless bully to woodpeckers; and generally that nature is fascinating but not nice, simply a well-design and efficient system to recycle all biomass as new life. Jack apologizes for not being a wildlife biologist, but he is an expert storyteller who makes what could be dry science come alive with personal experiences, characters and dialogue. He says he learned his craft while taking creative writing classes in high school in Greeley, Colorado. Then he honed this skill while bedridden and accepting assignments as term-paper ghost-writer. Knowing Jack only as an acquaintance, I suspect he is the rare natural writer. The story of Hacienda Baru is a hopeful one for the future of our natural environment and resources. Since letting Hacienda Baru "go native" and linking to other habitat areas through wildlife corridors, the Ewings have witnessed an explosion in the diversity and recurrence of native species. These include white-faced monkeys, toucan, coati, jaguar and panther. With the ecosystem more in balance from the bottom to the top of the food chain, Hacienda Baru has also seen a reduction of pests such as mosquitos, who once found halvah in the rice paddies. We stayed three days and were amazed by the diversity of life but bit once or twice. Unlike almost other "companion" books, which take a scrapbook approach, this one has real substance and easily stands alone (although my mother tells me the DVD of the series is also excellent). She must have worked it for hours at her foot-pedal sewing machine and at Grandpa Mike's workbench. Though it broke my heart to tell her this (and probably hers to my rue to this day), I could not wear the outfit. The thought of approaching the doorstep of all those VFW dads who served in Guadalcanal and Normandy and Iceland (my Dad) and whose sons were about to march off to 'Nam--the thought of approaching them as a semi-obscure Portugese explorer in tights--I just couldn't do it. Among my peers I was already suspected to be a "fem" (their word). What can I say, I was a gentle soul. I provisioned Halloween at the Army Navy Store and went with gas mask bag, fatigues and helmet as Vic Morrow's sergeant in "Combat." That was 1963.But I never forgot Magellan. He was like the slatternly, semi-psychotic girlfriend of yore who you were lucky to escape from, but you always, wonder, What if? (Well maybe not quite.) So I was delighted to find this book on a remainder table and it was quite okay. Bergeen is a thoughtful and scrupulous historian who puts you in the place of of a hapless Spanish crewman put out to sea for more than three years under the ruthless rule of a Portugese religious zealot and military ultradisciplinarian, a kind of Christian Brother for the 16th century. It seems Moses shaped the entire waterfront including the crests of the waves. I was driven on his parkways (Belt to see grandma, Meadowbrook to get to Jones Beach). He shaped the 1963 World's Fair (a money loser) and eventually gained control of a half-dozen public agencies. The Moses name seemed to loom on every construction sign and cast a long shadow over even the egomaniac Governor Rockefeller. Moses' own megalomania was documented in Robert Caro's tragic biography "The Power Broker," a Shakespearian tale of genius gone wrong in which Moses is blamed for just about everything that went wrong with American cities and suburbs after WW II--misbegotten public housing, decaying public transit, numbing sprawl, traffic jams, you name it. Jane Jacobs was his foil--an autodidactic Greenwich Village "housewife" who became a writer for Architectural Record and ultimately of "The Death and Life of American Cities," a polemic in defense of the small, spontaneous and neighborly, rather than the planned megaproject. Jacobs' book remains a classic 50 years later while Moses (despite some efforts to rehab his reputation) is largely reviled as the devil of top-down, arrogant, urban soul-sucking planning. Like Godzilla vs. Mothra, the two titans faced off in Greenwich Village in the early 1960s. The forces of Jacobs triumphed over a Moses highway scheme and today we have an intact SoHo to show for it. Roberta Brandes Gratz grew up in a Greenwich Village neighborhood that was ripped down for urban renewal. Her family (art-appreciating owners of a dry cleaning operation) moved to Weston, Connecticut, a rural idyll that Gratz saw overrun by cookie-cutter suburbia. She found her way back to Manhattan by way of NYU, went to work on the New York Post (with Pete Hamill and Jack Newfield), discovered architecture, and later became a celebrated writer on architecture and planning. Gratz takes a personal view of the Moses vs. Jacobs debate, having lived through it at close personal range. This is not really an urban planning book but a charming memoir of growing up in New York and its suburbs and of a young Jewish intellectual woman coming of age during an era of powerful women who really did change the world--Jacobs, Rachel Carson and Betty Friedan among them. Just a few years before his death, Steinbeck set out with a big poodle and a specially appointed camper-top pickup to find America and he found it in bits and shards. For a famous populist he did not seem to engage much with felllow Americans. I estimate the book recounts less than a dozen encounters over the course of months and thousands of miles. Steinbeck hates cities and avoids them, thus skipping 90 percent of the populace to begin with. (Note: I recall driving vacations through cities of the Northeast at this time and they were pretty dreary and congested.) On the other hand there are long disquistions on subjects like the rise of mobile home parks and how you can tell when to trust a veterinarian. Still this is worth reading to compare the America of 1962 to today. Slightly before the rise of major fast-food chains, Steinbeck complained about the sameness of roadside food everywhere. He worries that regional accents will disappear yet they are still with us.People seemed loathe to discuss politics and did not wear their affiliations on their sleeves or bumper stickers--unless you mentioned the USSR, a topic everyone agreed on. Perhaps the nation united against the Red was too preoccupied to argue with each other. Race was a big issue. Eight years after Brown vs. Board, Steinbeck was drawn to the spectacle of huge protests outside a New Orleans public school where a tiny black girl had enrolled. Daily she was escorted into the building while a chorus a local moms (dubbed "the Cheerleaders") led a bulging crowd shouting vicious epithets. Yet the (too) moderate Steinbeck worried aloud that blacks would advance too fast, ultimately damaging their own cause by creating a backlash. Steinbeck's tone is cranky but unthreatening, like some old opinionated codger (although he was only 57) you might meet in a KOA campground. His suburban peregrination is nothing like "On the Road." In this imperfect but worthwhile narrative, Reston links the rise of Spain as a religious monarchy, primarily powered by war and the Inquisition, to consolidation of power and ultimately the conquest of colonization of new lands. He does a good job of drawing and humanizing such characters of Isabelle, Ferdinand, the Inquisitor Torquemada, the upstart, social climbing Columbus, Pope Alexander and his vile bastard offspring, the Borgias, and many more obscure historical figures. Granted this is a complex narrative but Reston hurts his cause (for most of the book) by offering too much detail, too many characters. Stay with it as he gains momentum in the last one-third as the Spanish monarchs close in on the final outpost of Granada (taken in an anti-climactic capitulation from the well-named Boabdil the Unfortunate, the final Moorish caliph of Andalusia). I learned that Columbus, who was elevated to royal status after his 1492-93 expeditions, led two far less successful explorations and died more or less a miserable failure. Note: I visited many of these sites a few months ago, for example, Seville, one of the world's most charming, exotic and picturesque cities. I learned that the plaza outside the cathedral where I sat sniffing orange blossoms and listening to classical guitar and flamenco was the site of a gruesome podium/smudge pot where hundreds of "heretics" were burned at the stake. And why did the Inquisitors burn at the stake? Because of churchly prescriptions that no blood be spilled in the "relaxation" (this the actual term they used) of heretics. Finally I praise the author for maintaining a relatively balanced point of view. Only when you get to the epilogue does he reveal a somewhat politcally correct point of view. What the "nesters" went through is not imaginable. Dust storms that could last a month with gale-force winds clogging their homes and dugouts and of course their lungs. Parches months when ground temps could reach 150. The hostility of a nation--disbelieving to the East until the Dust Storms actually migrated to NY and DC, and gripped by a kind of anti-immigration fervor to the West, where Californians erected "No Okies Welcome" signs as far east as Tulsa. Egan explores the lives of of about 10 "nester" families (and their briefly thriving communities) who moved to the southern Great Plains expecting a bonanza and received in the form a rainy decade (1920s) and record grain prices. Expecting even greater profits they plowed up millions of acres of prairie grasses and topsoil that had evolved gently over millenia. Then the Great Depression hits; grain prices plummet and finally a 10-year drought ensues. Spoiler alert: The book lacks a gratifying conclusion. You are primed for Roosevelt and the WPA to ride to the rescue but their flagship reclamation projects flops when contour-plowed fields are attacked by locusts. The Dust Bowl simply seems to end in a spirit of semi-formal cooperation to change ag practices; while ag is doomed anyway. Egan's point seems to be cautionary, not inspirational. The stories of survival are not uplifting. They just leave you wondering why the stragglers did not leave this land where you might not see a single green thing grow for five years. Their fight overcomes their flight seeming to negate their own survival in many cases. Billy was a beloved songster and storyteller in the bars and a different (or rather indifferent) person at home. He showed little interest in his son's burgeoning interests in art and letters with never a kind word or hand for his classically long-suffering Irish-American wife and their slowly growing brood (7 kids over 21 years). Pete manages to draw an affectionate portrait of Billy and love him as well as his saintly mother. Drinking Life is strong on the details of a working class childhood that straddles the Depression and WWII: games played on rooftops involving dares to leap over airshafts. review: The great garment district fire of 1911 killed 146 people in Lower Manhattan. This was the greatest workplace loss of life for decades before and 90 yThe great garment district fire of 1911 killed 146 people in Lower Manhattan. This was the greatest workplace loss of life for decades before and 90 years after, until 9/11/2001. The average factory loft (today converted into a swanky condo) was 10 or 11 stories, meaning four floors beyond the reach of the highest hook and ladder. Fire escapes were grossly inadequate and no-smoking rules usually ignored. Scrap heaps beneath each work table provided a highly combustible matrix--and cotton is incredible friable. Fire equipment in the building consisted of a water bucket placed here and there and a few fire hoses that malfunctioned when needed. The book is an unsparing account of what it was like to be an immigrant sweatshop worker, which was only a short step above slavery and so grim you might wish to perish in a fire. My Sicilian grandmother Maria Sgalambro was one of those workers doing a piecemeal jobs on a foot-pumped cast-iron sewing machine that we later kept in our house like some kind of trophy. But she worked at home sewing ornamental collars on shirtwaists (blouses), not in a factory. My mother was born in a tenement on what is now the Silk Stocking district, the Upper East Side. Like many immigrant families, her's moved often to take advantage of a month's free rent offered by landlords during the Great Depression. On another personal note, I just moved my office to the sixth floor of a building constructed in 1892. After reading this, I plan to install a coiled rope anchored on the balcony. The writer (a Washington Post reporter) does a very good job with grim subjects: not just the grisly details of the fire (of 146 deaths, about half were burns and the other half jumped eight stories or fell off a failed fire escape); but Russian pograms and the Southern Italian droughts and volcanos (factors that drove Jews and Sicilians to emigrate); tenements, sweatshops, arson and the complicit role of insurance companies who discouraged fire safety; and the sorting out of charred and crushed bodies on the piers of Manhattan (a ghastly scene re-created on a larger scale after 9/11). Our oil addiction stemmed from the discovery of oil "seep fields" (think of teh Beverly Hillbillilies "bubblin' crude") in Western Pa. The original oil boom sought to exploit kerosene as an improvement over whale oil burning in lamps. Oil fever waxed and waned until the commercialization of internal combustion, which transformed the US in a mere decade and is still transforming the world. The story of oil is the story of huge historical themes and events: the rise and fall and rise of monopolies in the U.S.; the Bolshevik revolution; and the colonization of "protectorates" in Mesopotamia to create states like Iraq. Oil was the lynchpin resource of both World Wars. In WWII the Allies destroyed Rumanian oilfields in a race against time against marching Germans and Turks. In a lesser-known variation on the Miracle of Dunkirk, the French discovered the utility of internal combustion when the military drafted thousands of Parisian cab drivers to transport troops to the front against marching Germans. Without this improvised troop movements (and yes the cabbies were encouraged to run their meters), the Germans could have easily taken the capital and possibly ended the war with a different result. Suddenly cavalry was "out." Tanks (a code name that stuck) were invented to break the gridlock imposed by trench warfare. Internal combustion also fueled dogfights in the sky. In months airplanes went from unreliable toys to 150 mph fighting machines, which were made obsolete by a new generation of war planes in only another six months. In WWII we outproduced the Axis as much as defeated them. Yergin set out to depict a fascinating historical sweep through an oil-filled prism. He is partially successful. He vividly recreates characters like Rockefeller, Teddy Roosevelt, and Marcus Samuel, the founder of Shell Oil who got his start selling curios and souvenirs covered in glued-on sea shells and also became Mayor of London. But the journey feels more episodic than sweeping as this very looonnnggg book is splintered into two- and three-page chapters, almost each commandeered by a new Superhero/Master of the Business or Political Universe. He also over-focuses on the business dealings of Big Oil, sometimes to the point of tedium but often to the exclusion of the social side of the story, such as: What was really happening in Mesopotamia while the region was being pawned between England and France? Some are abstract architectural tracts with all the readability of legal notices. This book is one of the better ones. Kahn's story is most popularly known through the documentary My Architect, by his bastard son Nathaniel. This book goes lightly over the ground of Kahn's quasi-bigamy and focuses on his creation of monumental buildings in India, Bangladesh, Philadephia, Fort Worth, and San Diego, among others. The book's main strength is that is is clear-eyed; the author does not idolize Kahn, who is revered in architecture as a mystical figure. This is also the book's main weakness. In revealing Kahn's may flaws, he books a huge chink into the legacy. For example, Kahn was notoriously impractical and many of his buildings simply did not work functionally or for the comfort of occupants. For example, the Phillips Exeter Academy had to spent $7 million to fix Kahn's mid-1960s library, which was built without insulation in New Hampshire. Ultimately Kahn comes off us as the consummately arrogant modern architect designing his buildings without concern for occupants, site, comfort, budget, or durability of materials. I have seen one Kahn building--the Salk Reserch Center in La Jolla, Calif.--and admired it greatly. He emerges from this portrait as a tarnished angel. And maybe that's okay. ...more
